titleInfo.title: 223HA3 Hixon Mound Site 1HA3, Hamilton Co., TN. Feature 68, Charred wood, cane and thatch lying directly on the floor. Note lattice work details of construction. Portion in the partly destroyed seat at extreme left of picture. Sq. 26L13. Direction northwest

mods.abstract: [Feature 68] Hard burned clay floor and associated wall trenches and post molds of a rectangular small pole structure. Floor S level. From the quantities of burned clay and fragmentary charcoal over and around this structure it had apparently burned after or during use. (Sketch on reverse side). Possibly a little more than half of the entire prepared floor area remained. Intrusive burial pits were partially responsible.... I did not suspect the structure extended so far to the west because of the absence of flooring. However the length of trench on the SE side suggests that its parallel mate was at least as long. Subsequent checking with earlier ground plans shows the possible extent of NW trench to the west by the presence of a few intermittant post molds. Feature 68 was no doubt an important structure in the village life at a time previous to mound construction.... No postmolds showed in the trench in contact with pit or immediately to the south. [Feature 75] Oblong block of dirt. Plastered on sides and part of top with mixed clay and sand subsequently burned. Possibly some sort of seat. This block was built up of made earth from the floor level of Feature 68 and plastered with a mixture of sandy clay - subsequently burned. It is long, low and oblong in shape with rounded corners and edges. Apparently the plastered surface was damaged in use or after destruction of Feature 68, because the surface was rough and broken. The damaged areas were restored accurately with mud before photographing the general layout of Feature 68.
mods.note: Additional narative information and observer illustrations available at the institution. See also photographs 224HA3 [fhm00897], 225HA3 [fhm00898], and 227HA3 [fhm00900].
